provenance.note: Acquired by Thomas Butts in 1805 from Blake; Thomas Butts, Jr., apparently by inheritance in 1845; Frederick J. Butts, apparently by inheritance in 1862; his widow by inheritance in 1905; sold 2 June 1905 to W. Graham Robertson; given 1939 by Robertson to the Tate Gallery (now Tate Collection).

objnote.p: In "Newton," the great scientist is represented as a heroically proportioned youth sitting at the bottom of the ocean. Sea creatures decorate the rocks below and behind him. Newton bends forward to measure a geometrical diagram on a partly unrolled scroll. Taken together, his environment and his actions indicate the descent of the human form divine into materialism and abstraction.
The title, "Newton," inscribed in pencil below the design, is almost certainly not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Newton, sitting in an underwater seascape, bends forward sharply at the waist to measure or draw a triangle containing an arc on a partially unrolled scroll. He uses dividers or compasses, which he holds in his left hand. With his right index finger he points toward the geometrical figure on the scroll. His hair is short and curly, and his body is youthful and muscular. His eyes look downward in an expression of concentration. Although he is nude, drapery falls from behind his body and covers the edge of the unrolled portion of the scroll. Newton sits on a ledge projecting from a cliff, large rock, or reef of some kind that appears to be covered with undersea creatures, animal and vegetable. Two tentacled creatures, perhaps sea anemones, grow beneath him and drift to the right with the current.

component.illusobjdesc: A youthful and muscular Newton, sitting in an underwater seascape, bends forward sharply at the waist to measure or draw a triangle containing an arc on a partially unrolled scroll. He is seen in right profile, with his head facing down. He uses dividers or compasses, which he holds in his left hand between his thumb and at least two fingers. His left arm must be bent at the elbow, and his wrist is bent downward to hold the compasses. His right arm is extended downward, and with his right index finger he points toward the figure on the scroll. Fingers, hands, feet, and right ear (the last partly covered by Newton's curly hair) are carefully delineated. His left leg is bent back, and his left foot rests behind his right. His hair is short and curly. His eyes look downward in an expression of concentration. Although he is nude, drapery (part of a cloak or robe?) falls from behind his body and covers the edge of the unrolled portion of scroll.
Newton holds dividers or compasses in his left hand, and uses them to measure a geometrical diagram.
Newton measures the geometrical diagram on a partially unrolled scroll. The rolled portion, on the far right, is coiled into a spiral.
The figure of a triangle containing an arc appears inscribed on the scroll.
Newton sits on a ledge projecting from a cliff or a large rock, possibly part of a reef or undersea mountain.

The cliff, rock, or reef on which Newton sits and the ground (or floor of the ocean) on the right is encrusted with seaweeds and other growths, some perhaps the undersea equivalents of mosses or lichens. The two creatures below his hip, with tentacles and branch-like short stems, may be sea anemones. To the left, the spiky forms may be the thorn-like spines of a sea urchin.

Newton appears to be pictured on the ocean floor, as suggested by the presence of sea creatures and the deep blue-green background above and to the right. This may be the sea of time and space in Blake's mythological imagery. The tentacles below Newton's hip stream out to the right, thereby indicating the presence of a current (the underwater equivalent of a wind) moving from left to right.
